results.title: The History of writing
results.brief_description: Divided into four parts. Discusses and illustrates the origins of picture writing; the writing systems of China, Mesopotamia, and Egypt; the emergence of the first real alphabet in Palestine and Syria; the spread of this alphabet to Greece and Rome; and the development of the Roman script through the Middle Ages until the invention of printing.

results.title: The History of Totalitarianism
results.brief_description: Images are flashed in rapid succession of tyrants, artefacts and symbols of oppression from the days of Cheops to the present, to portray a quick history of man’s oppression of man. A musical score of contrasting rhythms underscores the philosophical message. Without narration.

results.title: The History of the world in three minutes flat
results.creator_credit: Michael Mills and Michael Mills Productions
results.brief_description: Uses vignettes from the past and animators’ licence to provide a humorous account of history as seen through the eyes of “The Creator”. With animation by Jim Hiltz, Bill Speers, Rick Bowman and John Gaug.

results.title: The History of the helicopter
results.creator_credit: Sarah Erulkar and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The growth of vertical flight from the early experiments of Leonardo da Vinci and others to the development of the modern helicopter. A feature of the film is a sequence made up of extracts from early newsreels.

results.title: The History of the cinema
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A graphic record of moving pictures from the first glimmer in the mind of men to the film as we know it today, and maybe as we will know it tomorrow. A cartoon based on facts, it depicts the cave artist; the invention of the motion picture camera; the silent era to the talkies; the impact of television; and the motion picture industry’s effort to combat it by widening the screen and eventually evolving a circular screen. Credits include: animation by Harold Whitaker, John Smith; story by John Halas, Nicholas Spargo; photography by Bill Taylor, Roy Turk; music by Jack King and commentary by Maurice Denham.

results.title: The History of inventions
results.creator_credit: Bruno Bozzetto, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Bozetto claims that it was lightning that first showed man the wonders of fire and set him on the hazardous path of invention. Since primitive times man’s inventive itch has never been at rest; now we finds ourselves living on a planet so endangered by our inventions that we may well have to escape to another world to find the peace necessary to go on inventing. In English and Italian.

results.title: The History book. 5. Triumphant symphony
results.creator_credit: The Film Front and Tricontinental Film Center
results.brief_description:
Fifth in a series of nine animated films on the history of Western Civilization. Looks at the Industrial Revolution and some of its effects: the movement of people into the cities; the use of child labour; the exploitation of workers; the movement of capitalists into parliament to further their own interests and their use of police to quell the workers’ complaints; and the development of monopolies. English version by Tricontinental Film Center.
Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Historic route
results.creator_credit: Yemi Lijadu and United Nations Films
results.brief_description: Ethiopia has the most remarkable collection of monuments in the whole of Africa apart from the Mediterranean area, and the “historic route” is the richest in the country. The restoration and preservation of monuments as well as the development of sites are essential elements in the growth of tourism in the country’s economy.
